attributes.comment:
I am writing to express my concern regarding the proposed increase in the fees
for the I600A application. As an adoptive parent I have twice gone through the
I600A application to adopt a child from China with USCIS in Miami in the past
couple of years.

While I understand that the fees we pay toward our application are used for
other services offered by USCIS, I am disappointed that prospective adoptive
parents (especially those adopting from China) are going to suffer yet another
financial hurdle. Since the process time-lines from China have increased to
over 18 months, families are now being asked to incur the I600A fees twice prior
to being united with their child. At the proposed rate increase this would mean
an average cost of $1660 against the present $685, an increase of 140%!!! This
is unreasonable and penalizes prospective adoptive parents and their children.
Do we really want to keep children from their parents? Shouldn't the government
try to assist those who want to make a positive difference in the society?
There are many people in the country who make no attempt to live by society's
rules,but yet again it it those who are law-abiding and honest that suffer.

Since the level of service for families has not improved and has even in most
cases become even more difficult and stressful, added to the fact that the INS
officers who are responsible for issuing the 171H have in effect doubled their
workload, (due to the 18 month expiry and subsequent re-application) it seems
hard to justify yet another increase in fees.

While I understand that the fees will increase no matter what my personal
opinion, I would like to voice my concern and support of all future adoptive
parents and request that the increase be shelved or better yet that the 171H
expiration period be extended for adoptive parents to accommodate the new longer
time-frames. This would also cut down the work of the officers who would not
have to deal with multiple applications for the same child.

Respectfully,
Kim Choi
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Kim Choi
